items.message: This flood alert remains in place. Areas most at risk include low lying areas in Tetbury, Badminton, Brook End at Luckington, Corsham, Lacock and the road at Reybridge. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Bristol Avon, Tetbury Avon, Sherston Avon, Dauntsey Brook, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected. Further rainfall is forecast today 05/12/25 and over the weekend. River levels are forecast to rise further in the coming days and the flood risk remains.

items.description: River Trent from Cromwell Weir to Gainsborough
items.message:
Areas most at risk are Church Laneham to Rampton Road. Further rain is forecast from this evening, however river levels at the Torksey Gauge will pose a flood risk around the high tide at 21:00 on 05/12/25. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 21:00 on 05 December 2025 or as the situation changes.

Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby and the Mountsorrel to Sileby road. Heavy rainfall is forecast over Friday evening, 05/12/2025. River levels at Pillings Lock gauge have peaked, but forecast rainfall could cause a further rise in levels. Levels are likely to remain high throughout the weekend. We are closely monitoring the situation. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 5:00PM on 05 December 2025 or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Churn, Hilcot Brook, Daglingworth Stream, Gumstool Brook

items.message:
High river levels may lead to flooding.

Flooding is possible from the morning of the 05 Dec 2025.

Flooding of low lying land and roads is possible today, along the River Churn around Cerney Wick. The weather forecast is for further rain which could be heavy at times over the next 3 days. We expect river levels to stay high.

We are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. Go to River levels online for updates on current river levels.

This message will be updated by 19:00 05 Dec 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames and its small tributaries from Calcutt to Lechlade

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Thames, Blunsdon Brook, Water Eaton Brook, Marston Meysey Brook, Share Ditch, Bydemill Brook, Westrop Brook, Downington Brook

items.message:
High river levels may lead to flooding.

Flooding is possible from the evening of the 05 Dec 2025.

Flooding of low lying land and roads is possible today, 05 Dec 2025, along the River Thames, especially in the Kempsford area. This is as a result of rivers responding to recent rainfall. The weather forecast is for further rain which could be heavy at times over the next 3 days. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. Go to River levels online for updates on current river levels.

This message will be updated by 1900 05 Dec 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: South East Somerset Rivers, Upper Reaches

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Yeo, River Cam, River Wriggle, Barwick Stream, West Coker Stream

items.message: Following last night's rain, river levels rose today, including at Sherborne Lake. While other rivers in the area have peaked and in some cases started to fall, Sherborne Lake is still gradually rising and remains above Alert level, and will likely stay high into tomorrow. Further heavy and persistent rain is forecast tomorrow, Friday 05/12/2025 and overnight into Saturday. This will keep the lake level high and will cause other local rivers to rise again, including the River Yeo, River Wriggle and River Cam. Flooding of low-lying land and roads is possible in this area, including around the Sparkford to Weston Bampfylde road and Deep Ford Lane, Chetnole. Therefore the need for this Alert remains. We are closely monitoring the situation, and checking defences, bridges, debris screens and culverts. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 16:00PM on 05/12/2025, or as the situation changes.

River levels are falling slowly but remain high and the potential for flooding continues today, 5 December 2025. Flooding may affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Wolverley to Newport. Other locations that may be affected include Market Drayton, Wem, and Rodington. We are closely monitoring the situation . Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 10:00AM on 6 December 2025 or as the situation changes

items.description: Upper Avon River Swift and Clay Coton Brook
items.message:
Forecast rising river levels today may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 04 December 2025 .at 18:00 
Locations most affected will be low lying land and roads near rivers. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water . 
This message will be updated by 11:30AM on 05 December 2025 or as the situation changes.

River levels are rising again at the Stinsford river gauge on the Lower Frome after overnight rainfall. Flooding is forecast to affect low lying areas to start with near to the River Frome in the Dorchester, West Stafford, Bockhampton, Lewell, Tincleton, Pallington, Waddock, Moreton, Wool, East Stoke, Holmebridge, Stoborough, Stoborough Green, Wareham, Redcliffe, Ridge and Swineham areas. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this Flood Alert if necessary. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. People in this area should take action now and watch your local weather forecast. This message will be updated by 09:00 AM on 5/12/2025, or as the situation changes.

Following high river levels this morning, and a relatively dry day since then, rivers further up the catchments have fallen below Alert level, such as the River Isle at Donyatt and at Ashford Mill. The River Parrett at Chiselborough has peaked and has just fallen below Alert level. Further downstream, the river levels are only just peaking, such as at Gaw Bridge and Kingsbury Episcopi on the Parrett, and at Hambridge on the Isle. Yet further downstream at Midelney, levels are still rising and should peak quite soon. Added to this, heavy persistent rain is forecast tomorrow, Friday 05/12/2025, into Saturday morning. Therefore, this Alert needs to stay in force as levels are still high on lower stretches of the river network, and it is a relatively short period until the next band of rain on Friday. Flooding of low-lying land and roads is still possible in this area. We are closely monitoring the situation. Take care, avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water, and stay vigilant for updates. This message will be updated by 3:00PM on 05/12/2025, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high but steady at the Lugwardine river gauge. Flooding continues today 5 December 2025. Flooding may affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Lugg south of Leominster from Stoke Prior to Mordiford. Other locations that may be affected include Bodenham, Lugwardine and Hampton Bishop. The levels at the Lugwardine guage are currently 2.69m and steady. We are closely monitoring the situation . Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water . This message will be updated by 10:00AM on 06 December 2025 or as the situation changes

floodArea.county: Bath and North East Somerset, Wiltshire

items.message: This flood alert remains in place. Areas most at risk include low lying land and roads between Melksham and Bathford. The flood gates at Holt Road may be closed. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Bristol Avon, Semington Brook, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected. Further rain is forecast today 05/12/25 and over the weekend. River levels will remain high and the flood risk continues for the coming days.

items.description: Rivers Clyst and Culm and their tributaries
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. 
Weather conditions are expected to improve and no further flooding is expected. However, a further band of rain is forecast throughout Friday and river levels are forecast to rise again. 
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.   
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. Stay away from floodwater - it contains hidden dangers such as open manhole covers, sewage and chemicals.

River levels remain high due to recent rainfall, flooding may continue over the next few days. Flooding may affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Severn from Tewkesbury to Gloucester. Locations that may be affected include Apperley, Maisemore, Hempstead, Minsterworth Ham and Quedgeley. The Severn Ham, Tewkesbury may start to fill.  

River levels are currently peaking and will remain high over the next few days. Additional rainfall is forecast Friday 05/12/2025 onwards, which may cause river levels to rise further.  

We are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  

This message will be updated by 09:00AM on 6 December 2025, or as the situation changes.

Locations most affected will be local roads and low-lying land around Stamford Bridge, Pocklington, Wressle, Wilberfoss and Elvington. The forecast remains unsettled this week and levels are expected to remain high. We are closely monitoring the situation. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 9PM on 05 December 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.message:
High river levels over the next two days may lead to flooding.   

Flooding is possible on Thursday 04 December and on Friday 05 December. 

River levels remain high and a further band of rain is expected on Friday.  

Forecast levels may cause flooding to low lying land and roads close to the river.  

We expect the river to remain high overnight and into tomorrow, though no flooding to properties is currently forecast.   

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels.   

Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. Avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.   

This message will be updated by 3:00PM on 05 December 2025 or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Horner Water, River Aller, Washford River, Hawkcombe Stream, Monksilver Stream, Doniford Stream

items.message:
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. 
Weather conditions are expected to improve and no further flooding is expected. Today, rivers have fallen below alert level and the risk of flooding has reduced. Heavy, persistent rain is forecast tomorrow, Friday 05/12/2025. 
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.  
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. Never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car. Please remain vigilant and prepared for further flood alerts.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
High tides today may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible from 12:15 pm to 04:15 pm on 05/12/2025. 
The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.75 mAOD at 02:15 PM on 05/12/2025.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. Flooding of properties is not expected.

Astronomical tide levels are rising. The river flow at Teddington Weir is 90 cubic metres per second and is rising. We anticipate the flows to rise  for the next few days. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water . 
This message will be updated by 7:00PM on 05 December 2025 or as the situation changes.

High tides on Friday may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible for 2 hours either side of Friday evening's tide at 23:30 on 05/12/2025. 
The weather increases tide table values by 0.25 m. Total forecast tide is 6.15 metres Chart Datum (3.10 mAOD) at Littlehampton. Strong South Westerly Force 6 wind. Small amounts of water will flood land and fields at Climping. Waves will overtop the sea front, directing water westwards along Mill Lane (from the right of the East car park) towards properties on Climping Street. Water may pond near property and in Climping Street Car Park. Saturday's tide at 11:45 06/12/2025 is forecast to be 3 cm lower (3.07 mAOD). Similar minor flood impacts are expected over all tides on Saturday and Sunday. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . We routinely check the condition of the beach at Climping. 
Consider activating any flood protection products you may have . Access could be restricted. Take care if visiting Climping beach. 
This message will be updated by 6:00PM on 06 December 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
High river levels may lead to flooding.  

Flooding is possible on Friday 05 December. 

A band of rain is expected on Friday.  

Forecast river levels may cause flooding to low lying land and roads close to the river. 

The main areas of concern are Yealmpton, Yealmbridge and Mill Bridge. 

We expect the river to remain high overnight on Friday, though no flooding to properties is currently forecast.  

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels.  

Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. Avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  

This message will be updated by 3:00PM on 05 December 2025 or as the situation changes.

There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. 
Coastal conditions are expected to improve and no flooding is expected.   
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.   
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. Never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car.

items.description: Plymouth Sound, Wembury Bay and tidal estuaries
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
High tides, strong winds and large waves over the next three days may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible over high tides from the evening of Friday 5th December to the morning of Tuesday 9th December. 
Low lying coastal roads, promenades, car parks and harbours may be flooded.

High tide at Plymouth on Friday evening is 17:51 and on Saturday morning at 06:12, times of high water will vary along the coast.  Forecast total high tide levels are 2.83mAOD and 2.91mAOD respectively. Expect tide levels along the coast to be around 0.5m above tide table level. Strong force 7 westerly winds and offshore wave heights of over 4.0m are forecast. 

The high tides of most concern are Saturday and Sunday mornings and flood warnings are likely to be issued. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Avoid coastal roads, footpaths and carparks, which may be flooded . 
This message will be updated by 2:00PM on 06 December 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal River Avon at Bristol, Pill and Shirehampton

floodArea.county: City of Bristol, North Somerset, South Gloucestershire

items.message:
High tides over the next two days may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible from 07:00PM to 08:00PM on 05/12/2025 and 07:00AM and 08:00AM on 06/12/2025 
Areas most at risk include the tidal River Avon from Sea Mills to Conham in Bristol and between the Avonmouth Bridge and Shirehampton Park including Pill and Shirehampton. The first forecast high water at Avonmouth is 7.48mAODN at 07:15pm this evening 05/12/2025, with South Westerly Force 5 winds. The second forecast high water is at 7:30am on Saturday 06/12/2025 with a level of 7.61mAODN and Force 7 South Westerly winds. mAODN is height above average sea level. Flooding to roads and farmland is possible but properties are not currently expected to flood. 
We are closely monitoring the situation and our incident response staff will be on site closing flood gates 
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water and don't put yourself or others at risk 
This message will be updated by 12:30PM on 06 December 2025 or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high and the potential for flooding remains today 05 December 2025 . Flooding may affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley. Roads between Maesbrook, Melverley and Pentre start to flood. Peaks:- Cae Howel is currently 4.15 and falling. We are closely monitoring the situation . Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water . This message will be updated by 10:00AM on 06 December 2025 or as the situation changes

items.message:
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. 
The previous tide of concern has now passed,  the weather is more settled and no flooding is expected.   
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.   
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. Never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car.

items.description: Severn estuary from Gloucester to Sharpness
items.message:
Higher than normal tides on Thursday evening and Friday morning may lead to flooding.  Flooding is possible from 8:30pm on Thursday evening and 9:00am on Friday morning.   

Flooding may affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the Estuary from Sandhurst to Chepstow and Sharpness over the next 5 days. Some lengths of the flood embankment at Longney and The Noards may be overtopped. Rodley Lane, Westbury and Awre Road, Brims Pill may be flooded. 

Predicted peaks: 

Thursday evening 04/12; Gloucester 3.1m to 3.4m at 8:30PM, Sandhurst 3.2m to 3.5m at 9:00pm. 
Friday morning 05/12; Gloucester 3.2m to 3.5m at 9:00AM, Sandhurst 3.4m to 3.7m at 9:15pm. 

We are closely monitoring the situation. 

Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. This message will be updated by 2:00PM on 05 December 2025 or as the situation changes.

There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. 
Coastal conditions are expected to improve and no flooding is expected.   
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.   
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. Never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car.

items.description: River Dee catchment in England from Whitchurch to Chester
items.message:
Rainfall on Thursday and Friday night into Saturday day will keep levels on the River Dee high. Levels will remain high over the weekend and into early next week. We are not expecting to reach Flood Warning levels. Access to Townfield could be impacted from late Saturday afternoon.

Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Dee. Flooding is possible at low lying land and roads around the River Dee at Shocklach, Farndon, Handley, Lower Kinnerton, Chester and Puddington.

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

This message will be updated by 16:00PM on 05 December 2025 or as the situation changes.

The flood forecast has changed significantly. As a result, there is no longer a risk of flooding in the area.

Flooding is possible over high tides on the evening of Friday 5th December and morning of Saturday 6th December. 
Low lying land, roads, and car parks may be flooded. Little Petherick is expected to be the first area to flood. 

High tide at Padstow on Friday evening is at 17:23 and on Saturday morning at 05:42, times of high water will vary along the coast. Forecast total high tide levels are 4.37mAOD and 4.28mAOD respectively. Expect tide levels along the coast to be 0.4 to 0.5m above tide table level. We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Avoid beaches and coastal promenades, which may be flooded .

items.description: North Cornwall coast from Chapel Porth to The Rumps excluding the tidal Camel Estuary
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
High tides, strong winds and large waves over the next two days may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible over high tides from the evening of Friday 5th December to the evening of Saturday 6th December. 
Low lying coastal roads, promenades, car parks and harbours may be flooded. 

High tide at St Ives on Friday evening is at 17:10 and on Saturday morning at 05:32, times of high water will vary along the coast. Forecast total high tide levels are 3.81mAOD and 3.78mAOD respectively. Expect tide levels along the coast to be 0.4 to 0.5m above tide table level. Strong force 7 westerly winds and offshore wave heights of up to 6.0m are forecast. 

The high tide of most concern is Saturday morning, and flood warnings maybe issued. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Avoid coastal roads, footpaths and carparks, which may be flooded . 
This message will be updated by 2:00PM on 06 December 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
High tides, strong winds and large waves are expected to cause flooding over the next two days.  
Flooding is expected over the morning high tides on Saturday 6th December and Sunday 7th December.  
Spray and wave overtopping of quaysides, harbours and low lying areas is expected to flood properties.

High tide at Falmouth on Saturday morning is at 05:41 and on Sunday morning at 06:32, times of high water will vary along the coast. Forecast total high tide levels are 2.62mAOD and 2.55m AOD respectively. Expect tide levels to be around 0.4m above tide table level. Strong force 7 westerly winds and offshore wave heights over 4.0m are forecast. 

Stormy conditions are expected to persist throughout the weekend and flood alerts may remain in force into next week.  
We are closely monitoring the situation .  
Avoid coastal roads, footpaths and carparks, which may be flooded and activate any flood protection products you may have  
This message will be updated by 2:00PM on 06 December 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.message:

Flooding is possible From Friday evening to Saturday morning. 
Areas particularly at risk include roads along the seafronts.
  
The high tide at Exmouth on Friday 5th is at 19:00, times of high water will vary along the coast.  Forecast total high tide level is 2.53mAOD, which is 0.55 metres above tide table level.  Force 5 SW winds and offshore wave heights of over 1.8m are forecast over the high tide. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Avoid coastal roads, footpaths and carparks, which may be flooded . 
This message will be updated by 1:00PM on 06 December 2025 or as the situation changes.

High river levels this morning may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible from the morning of 05 December 2025 . 
Locations most affected will be low lying land and roads near rivers.  Our forecasts indicate that flooding to properties is not likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water Avoid low lying roads, near rivers which may be flooded.. 
This message will be updated by 11:00AM on 06 December 2025 or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Brathay, River Rothay, River Winster

items.message: River and Lake levels remain high due to recent rainfall. Scattered showers, some of which may be heavy, are expected throughout today Thursday 4th December. Locations most affected will be low lying land and roads near rivers Brathay, Rothay, Winster and other watercourses from Grasmere to Grange-over-Sands including low lying areas around Ambleside, Skelwith Bridge, Windermere, Hawkshead, Newby Bridge, Backbarrow, Cark and Cartmel. We continue to monitor the situation. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 10AM on 05 December 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message: River and Lake levels remain high following recent heavy rainfall. Further scattered showers are expected today, Thursday 4/12/2025. Some of these showers will be heavy, which will keep river and lake levels elevated. We continue to monitor the situation. This message will be updated by 10:00AM on Friday 05 December 2025, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, Kingston upon Hull
floodArea.riverOrSea: Winestead Drain, Holderness Drain, Burstwick Drain, Skeffling Drain, Long Bank Drain, Keyingham Drain, Old Fleet Drain, Kellwell Stream, Lambwath Stream

items.message:
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. 
Weather conditions are expected to improve and no further flooding is expected.   
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.   
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. Never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car.

items.message: High river levels may lead to flooding. Flooding is possible over the next several days. Locations most affected will be low lying land and roads near Welham Bridge. The forecast remains unsettled this week. We are closely monitoring the situation. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 9PM on 05 December 2025 or as the situation changes.

High river levels are expected to continue to cause flooding in Buttercrambe today, Friday 05 December 2025. Locations most affected will be Buttercrambe Mill at Buttercrambe Bridge. Levels have peaked and remain steady. They are expected to decline marginally in the coming days. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 9PM on 05 December 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Great Ouse from Brackley to Thornborough
items.message:
High river levels today may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 05 December 2025  
Areas most at risk are those around the River Great Ouse from Brackley to Thornborough, including Padbury Brook.  We are not expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. 
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels . 
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses . 
This message will be updated by 5:00PM on 05 December 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.message:
High tides, strong winds and large waves over the next two days may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible from Friday evening to Saturday morning. 
Areas particularly at risk include Challaborough, Hope Cove, North and South Sands.
  
The high tide at Plymouth on Friday is at 05:45PM, times of high water will vary along the coast.  Forecast total high tide level is 2.83mAOD, which is 0.48 metres above tide table level. Strong force 7 westerly winds and offshore wave heights of up to 3.5m are forecast over the high tide. On Saturday the forecast total high tide level is 2.91mAOD at 06:00AM, which is 0.39 metres above tide table level. Strong force 7 westerly winds and offshore wave heights of up to 4.1m are forecast over the high tide. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Avoid coastal roads, footpaths and carparks, which may be flooded .
